title: Long Jump
question_text:
Data from the last $10\text{ years}$ shows that the average high school male has a personal best long jump of $18.9\text{ feet}$ with a standard deviation of $1.9\text{ feet}$. The average high school female has a personal best long jump of $16.5\text{ feet}$ with a standard deviation of $2.2\text{ feet}$. Both distributions are approximately normally distributed.
To earn All-Conference recognition, a jumper typically has to be $2$ standard deviations above the mean for their respective gender.
In a survey of $1{,}000$ female long jumpers, about how many girls would you expect to jump so well that they earn All-Conference recognition from not only the girls standard but also the boys standard?
solution:
To earn All-Conference recognition for the boys standard, the girls must jump $2$ or more standard deviations away from the mean of the boys standard. They must jump at least:

$$18.9+1.9+1.9 = 22.7\text{ feet}$$

Calculate the Z score of a girl who can jump $22.7\text{ feet}$:

$$\dfrac{(22.7-16.5)}{2.2} = 2.82$$

$\text{P(z < 2.82)} = .0024$ using the standard normal table.

Since there are $1{,}000$ girls surveyed, $1000 \cdot 0.0024 = 2.4$.

One would expect about $2$ (or $3$) girls to be this exceptional.

Thus, the correct answer is Choice 'C'.
